whatIs.title: What Is a Promissory Note?
items: A written, signed promise by one party (the borrower or maker) to pay a specific sum of money to another party (the lender or payee).
Can be payable on demand or at a specified future date.
Often includes terms like principal amount, interest rate, payment schedule, and late fees.
whatIs.lastParagraph: It's a fundamental instrument in finance, used for personal loans, business loans, student loans, and more.

headers: Why a Promissory Note is Crucial
rows: Lending money to friends or family
Avoids misunderstandings, clarifies terms, makes the loan enforceable.
Business loans or investments
Formalizes the debt, outlines repayment, protects both parties' interests.
Selling goods or services on credit
Serves as proof of debt and terms if payment isn't immediate.
Student loans
Legally required to document the obligation to repay educational funding.
Real estate financing (sometimes as part of a larger package)
Can secure a portion of the financing, separate from the mortgage itself.

varieties.title: Promissory Note Varieties
items: Simple Promissory Note: Basic promise to pay, often without complex terms.
Demand Promissory Note: Payable whenever the lender demands repayment.
Secured Promissory Note: Backed by collateral (e.g., a car or property) that the lender can claim if the borrower defaults.
Unsecured Promissory Note: Not backed by collateral; relies solely on the borrower's promise to pay.
Installment Promissory Note: Repaid in regular installments (e.g., monthly) over a set period.

rows: Principal Amount
The initial sum of money borrowed.
Interest Rate
The percentage charged on the loan, if any (check state usury laws).
Date of Note
When the promise to pay is made.
Parties (Lender & Borrower)
Full legal names and addresses of all involved.
Repayment Terms
How and when the loan will be repaid (installments, lump sum, due date).
Maturity Date
The final date by which the loan must be fully repaid.
Default Terms
What happens if the borrower fails to pay as agreed (e.g., late fees, acceleration clause).
Governing Law
Which state's or province's laws will apply to the note.
Signatures
Makes the note legally binding.

stateRules.title: State-Specific Rules & Usury Caps
stateRules.content: Usury laws limit the maximum interest rate a lender can charge. These rates vary significantly by U.S. state and Canadian province. Our template helps you by providing guidance, but always verify your local jurisdiction's current limits. Some states also have specific requirements for witness signatures or notarization, especially for larger loan amounts.
items: Research your state/province's maximum legal interest rate (usury limit).
Check if witness signatures are required or recommended.
Determine if notarization is necessary for the loan amount or type.

checklist.title: Lender & Borrower Checklist
items: Verify legal names and addresses of all parties.
Agree on all terms (amount, interest, repayment) before signing.
Both parties receive a signed copy of the note.
Keep payment records meticulously.
If secured, properly record any liens on collateral.
Understand default conditions and remedies.

q1.question: What's the difference between a loan agreement and a promissory note?
q1.answer: A promissory note is generally simpler and focuses on the promise to pay. A loan agreement is typically more comprehensive, detailing extensive terms, conditions, representations, and warranties for both parties, especially for complex business loans.

q2.question: Can I charge any interest rate I want?
q2.answer: No. Most states and provinces have usury laws that cap the maximum legal interest rate. Charging above this can make the interest (or even the entire loan) unenforceable. Always check your local laws.

q3.question: Does a promissory note need to be notarized?
q3.answer: It varies by jurisdiction and the loan amount. While not always legally required for validity between the parties, notarization adds a layer of authenticity and can be beneficial if the note needs to be enforced in court.

q4.question: What happens if the borrower doesn't pay?
q4.answer: The lender can take legal action to recover the debt, as outlined in the note's default clause. This might include sending demand letters, suing in small claims court, or pursuing other collection methods. If the note is secured, the lender may also have rights to the collateral.

q5.question: Can I use this template for a business loan?
q5.answer: Yes, this template can be adapted for simple business loans between individuals or entities. For very complex commercial lending, a more detailed Loan Agreement might be advisable. Consult a legal professional if unsure.
